instruction:
Greetings! I am interested in natural language processing and I was wondering if you could help me generate an example of text that illustrates multiple skills in semantics or syntax. The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Basketball that illustrates all of the following skills: anchoring (cognitive bias), antonymy. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**anchoring (cognitive bias)**: a psychological phenomenon in which an individual's judgements or decisions are influenced by a reference point or "anchor" which can be completely irrelevant. For example, "Individuals may be more likely to purchase a pricy car if it is placed next to an extremely expensive car."
**antonymy**: a lexical relation in which words have opposite meanings. For example, "Shallow" is an antonym of "deep".

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: During a basketball game, ten points felt like a tiny lead to James, but a huge deficit when his team was behind.<|endoftext|>

instruction:

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**complex question (loaded question with implicit assumption )**: A question that is loaded with an implicit assumption. For example, "Why are you lying to me?" is a question that presupposes you are lying to me. Any answer you give will force you to agree you are lying.
**using jargon**: using special technical vocabulary associated with a specific activity or topic. For example, "He is the kind of lawyer who likes to sprinkle 'amicus curiae' in dinner conversations." Here, "amicus curiae" is an example of jargon.

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**topicalization (syntax mechanism)**: A mechanism of syntax that establishes an expression as the sentence or clause topic by having it appear at the front of the sentence or clause (as opposed to in a canonical position further to the right). For example, "Because the pressure was too great, everyone refused to answer."
**argumentum ad populum**: a fallacious argument which is based on claiming a truth or affirming something is good because the majority thinks so. For example, "Everyone is going to get the new smart phone when it comes out this weekend. You should too!"

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

instruction:

The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Broadway play that illustrates all of the following skills: complex question (loaded question with implicit assumption ), cliché. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**complex question (loaded question with implicit assumption )**: A question that is loaded with an implicit assumption. For example, "Why are you lying to me?" is a question that presupposes you are lying to me. Any answer you give will force you to agree you are lying.
**cliché**: An element of an artistic work, saying, or idea that has become overused to the point of losing its original meaning or effect, even to the point of being weird or irritating, especially when at some earlier time it was considered meaningful or novel. For example, "All that glitters is not gold" has been used so often, it is now cliché.

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Given your lines are as chilly as yesterday’s ham, do you still believe ‘the show must go on’?”<|endoftext|>

**answer ellipsis**: An ellipsis (omission of speech) that occurs in answers to questions. For example, "'Who walked the dog?' asked Mary. 'Sam,' replied Jill."  This is an example of answer ellipsis, as Jill’s complete answer would have been "Sam walked the dog".
**slippery slope (argument)**: The assumption that a small change will cascade to a larger series of (undesirable) changes. For example, "Changing the grading standards will have a ripple effect throughout the college."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**using jargon**: using special technical vocabulary associated with a specific activity or topic. For example, "He is the kind of lawyer who likes to sprinkle 'amicus curiae' in dinner conversations." Here, "amicus curiae" is an example of jargon.
**category mistake (rhetorical error)**: An error in which things belonging to a particular category are presented as if they belong to a different category. For example, A visitor to Oxford was being given a tour. The visitor, upon viewing the colleges and library, reportedly inquired, "But where is the University?"

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!

**fallacy of composition**: Assuming that something is true of the whole from the fact that it is true of some part of the whole. For example, "If someone stands up from their seat at a cricket match, they can see better. Therefore, if everyone stands up, they can all see better."
**hypocorism**: A pet name. Also a word formation process in which a longer word is reduced to a shorter word ending with “ie’ or “y”, often affectionately. For example, "Telly" is a hypocorism for "television"; "movie" is a hypocorism for "motion picture."

Thanks very much!

instruction:
Greetings! I am interested in natural language processing and I was wondering if you could help me generate an example of text that illustrates multiple skills in semantics or syntax. The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Guerilla warfare that illustrates all of the following skills: allusion (literary reference), ad hominem. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**allusion (literary reference)**: Allusion is a figure of speech, in which an object or circumstance from an unrelated context is referred to covertly or indirectly. For example, Describing two people in a relationship as “star-crossed lovers” is an allusion to the Shakespeare play Romeo and Juliet.
**ad hominem**: a rhetorical strategy where the speaker attacks the character, motive, or some other attribute of the person. For example, "Boss, you heard my side of the story why I think Bill should be fired and not me. Now, I am sure Bill is going to come to you with some pathetic attempt to weasel out of this lie that he has created."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Commander Philips, with his predictable 'Waterloo' tactics, it's clear old dogs can't learn new tricks."<|endoftext|>

**anchoring (cognitive bias)**: a psychological phenomenon in which an individual's judgements or decisions are influenced by a reference point or "anchor" which can be completely irrelevant. The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Sushi that illustrates all of the following skills: begging the question or assuming the conclusion, topicalization (syntax mechanism). Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**begging the question or assuming the conclusion**: A circular argument that paraphrases the question. For example, "Of course the earth is round; people have known this for hundreds of years."
**topicalization (syntax mechanism)**: A mechanism of syntax that establishes an expression as the sentence or clause topic by having it appear at the front of the sentence or clause (as opposed to in a canonical position further to the right). For example, "Because the pressure was too great, everyone refused to answer."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Because it's often first to run out, Ebi must be the favorite sushi at any party."<|endoftext|>

instruction:

The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Sledding that illustrates all of the following skills: tautology (language), fallacy of division. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**tautology (language)**: a statement that repeats an idea, using near-synonymous morphemes, words or phrases, effectively "saying the same thing twice". For example, "You're simply going to have to score more points than the other team to win the game."
**fallacy of division**: Assuming that something that is true for a whole must also be true of all or some of its parts. For example, "Americans eat a lot of hamburgers. Bob is American. Therefore Bob eats a lot of hamburgers."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "All sledders, who enjoy the excitement of sledding, surely love sledding; Susan is a sledder, so she must enjoy the excitement."<|endoftext|>

**fallacy of composition**: Assuming that something is true of the whole from the fact that it is true of some part of the whole. For example, "If someone stands up from their seat at a cricket match, they can see better. Therefore, if everyone stands up, they can all see better."

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**complex question (loaded question with implicit assumption )**: A question that is loaded with an implicit assumption. For example, "Why are you lying to me?" is a question that presupposes you are lying to me. Any answer you give will force you to agree you are lying.
**answer ellipsis**: An ellipsis (omission of speech) that occurs in answers to questions. For example, "'Who walked the dog?' asked Mary. 'Sam,' replied Jill."  This is an example of answer ellipsis, as Jill’s complete answer would have been "Sam walked the dog".

instruction:
Greetings! I am interested in natural language processing and I was wondering if you could help me generate an example of text that illustrates multiple skills in semantics or syntax. The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Consequentialism that illustrates all of the following skills: tautology (language), accident (fallacy). Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**tautology (language)**: a statement that repeats an idea, using near-synonymous morphemes, words or phrases, effectively "saying the same thing twice". For example, "You're simply going to have to score more points than the other team to win the game."
**accident (fallacy)**: an informal fallacy and a deductively valid but unsound argument occurring in a statistical syllogism (an argument based on a generalization) when an exception to a rule of thumb is ignored.  For example, Cutting people with knives is a crime. Surgeons cut people with knives. Surgeons are criminals.

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Consequentialism always regards a good deed as one that brings about positive consequences, much like surgeons, termed as criminals, due to the harm caused by their surgical knives."<|endoftext|>

Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**complex question (loaded question with implicit assumption )**: A question that is loaded with an implicit assumption. For example, "Why are you lying to me?" is a question that presupposes you are lying to me. Any answer you give will force you to agree you are lying.
**hyperbole**: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally. For example, "I had to wait at the station for ten days—an eternity." Here, "an eternity" is a hyperbole.

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

**post hoc ergo propter hoc**: A fallacy of the form “after this, therefore because of this”. For example, "'Why are you whistling?' 'To keep the elephants away.' 'But there are no elephants around here.' 'See? It works.'"

**slippery slope (argument)**: The assumption that a small change will cascade to a larger series of (undesirable) changes. For example, "Changing the grading standards will have a ripple effect throughout the college."
**answer ellipsis**: An ellipsis (omission of speech) that occurs in answers to questions. For example, "'Who walked the dog?' asked Mary. 'Sam,' replied Jill."  This is an example of answer ellipsis, as Jill’s complete answer would have been "Sam walked the dog".

The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Jazz music that illustrates all of the following skills: topicalization (syntax mechanism), rhetorical question. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**topicalization (syntax mechanism)**: A mechanism of syntax that establishes an expression as the sentence or clause topic by having it appear at the front of the sentence or clause (as opposed to in a canonical position further to the right). For example, "Because the pressure was too great, everyone refused to answer."
**rhetorical question**: A question asked in order to create a dramatic effect or to make a point rather than to get an answer. For example, "How could you be so stupid?"

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Jazz, why wouldn't it charm the listeners with its distinctive rhythm and improvisation?"<|endoftext|>

instruction:
Greetings! I am interested in natural language processing and I was wondering if you could help me generate an example of text that illustrates multiple skills in semantics or syntax. The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Ancient Greece that illustrates all of the following skills: argumentum ad populum, hyperbole. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**argumentum ad populum**: a fallacious argument which is based on claiming a truth or affirming something is good because the majority thinks so. For example, "Everyone is going to get the new smart phone when it comes out this weekend. You should too!"
**hyperbole**: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally. For example, "I had to wait at the station for ten days—an eternity." Here, "an eternity" is a hyperbole.

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Beloved Greeks, every soul from the rising to the setting sun knows, our hero Hercules could single-handedly lift Mount Olympus to the sky!"<|endoftext|>

**begging the question or assuming the conclusion**: A circular argument that paraphrases the question. For example, "Of course the earth is round; people have known this for hundreds of years."

**ad hominem**: a rhetorical strategy where the speaker attacks the character, motive, or some other attribute of the person. **tautology (language)**: a statement that repeats an idea, using near-synonymous morphemes, words or phrases, effectively "saying the same thing twice". For example, "You're simply going to have to score more points than the other team to win the game."

**hypocorism**: A pet name. Also a word formation process in which a longer word is reduced to a shorter word ending with “ie’ or “y”, often affectionately. For example, "Telly" is a hypocorism for "television"; "movie" is a hypocorism for "motion picture."
**fallacy of composition**: Assuming that something is true of the whole from the fact that it is true of some part of the whole. For example, "If someone stands up from their seat at a cricket match, they can see better. Therefore, if everyone stands up, they can all see better."

The example should be a minimal natural piece of text with up to a few lines in the context of Ballroom dancing that illustrates all of the following skills: diversion, antimetabole. Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**diversion**: A tactic where the arguer diverts attention away from the relevant conclusion. For example, The prosecutor claims without proof the defendant is guilty of child abuse. The prosecutor then goes on and on about how awful child abuse is, instead of proving the original claim of the defendant’s guilt.
**antimetabole**: the repetition of words in successive clauses, but in transposed order. For example, "Ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "In ballroom dancing, accelerations demand your courage, yet courage demands your accelerations, and yet why discuss techniques when the dance floor awaits?"<|endoftext|>

instruction:

Please keep the text as short as possible, and make sure the concepts can be found fully from the text. 

For reference, here are the definitions and examples for the concepts:
**cliché**: An element of an artistic work, saying, or idea that has become overused to the point of losing its original meaning or effect, even to the point of being weird or irritating, especially when at some earlier time it was considered meaningful or novel. For example, "All that glitters is not gold" has been used so often, it is now cliché.
**begging the question or assuming the conclusion**: A circular argument that paraphrases the question. For example, "Of course the earth is round; people have known this for hundreds of years."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
output: Answer: "Of course, sushi is healthy; after all, it's just like life, a matter of balance."<|endoftext|>

**non sequitur**: An argument where the conclusion does not follow from the premises. For example, "'Why are you wearing your shirt backwards?' 'There will be a lunar eclipse tonight.'"
**hypocorism**: A pet name. Also a word formation process in which a longer word is reduced to a shorter word ending with “ie’ or “y”, often affectionately. For example, "Telly" is a hypocorism for "television"; "movie" is a hypocorism for "motion picture."

Please start the minimal natural piece of text with 'Answer:'.

Thanks very much!
